I forgot, there's one more question, that came to mind when I played NERO. =
The bots never fire a weopen when they don't see an enemy, but they never h=
ad to learn this behaviour. Consequently the question comes up, if that's j=
ust for simplicity and a network should actually learn everything or if it'=
s really better to set up some rules about what makes sense and what does a=
bsolutely not.

Cheers,
Daniel


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel" <dan=
iel_kuppitz@...> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I have a general question =
regarding the learning process.
> 
> After playing around with NERO the las=
t days, I've learned a lot about how networks learn, but I still found no a=
nswer to this elementary question: In which sequence should I train a netwo=
rk that has to solve more than one task. NERO isn't build with HyperNEAT, b=
ut I think my questions target HyperNEAT as well as NEAT.
> 
> Consider 9 s=
tages:
> 
> Network is ...
> 
>   1: quite good in task #1
>   2: really go=
od in task #1
>   3: perfect in task #1
>   4: quite good in task #2
>   5:=
 really good in task #2
>   6: perfect in task #2
>   7: quite good in task=
 #1 and #2
>   8: really good in task #1 and #2
>   9: perfect in task #1 a=
nd #2
> 
> Obviously I'll begin with stage 1, but what's next? Should I con=
tinue to train my network in this task (continue with stage 2) or should I =
switch to the next task (stage 4/7) and come back to stage 2 later.
> The n=
ext question is: How should I calculate the fitness when the network is tra=
ined in task #2.  Should solutions for task #2 be rewarded higher than thos=
e for task #1 (stage 4) or should solutions for task #1 still get the same =
reward as in stage 1 (stage 7)?
> 
> Maybe there's no general answer to my =
questions, but what's the best practice? What makes sense, what does not?
>=
 
> Cheers,
> Daniel
>
